title-group.article-title: Smithian-Aged (Early Triassic, Early Olenekian) Crinoid Ossicles from Exotic Limestone Blocks in the Lower Part of the Thaynes Formation at Crittenden Springs, Elko County, Nevada

contrib-group.aff: 1 Osaka Museum of Natural History, 1-23 Nagai Park, Higashi-sumiyoshi-ku, Osaka 546-0034, Japan
2 1134 Johnson Ridge Lane, West Jordan, Utah 84084, United States of America

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: We document the occurrence of Early Triassic (Olenekian) crinoid ossicles in exotic blocks contained within the black limestone unit of the Thaynes Formation, which overlies the Dinwoody Formation at the classic Crittenden Springs Smithian ammonoid locality. Crinoid ossicles include two species, i.e., Holocrinus sp. and Articulata ord., fam., gen. et sp. indet. Furthermore, two co-occurring, age diagnostic conodonts, i.e., Neospathodus pakistanensis and Ns. posterolongatus, constrain the age of the crinoids from the early Smithian to the earliest middle Smithian. This discovery represents the third report of Smithian Holocrinidae in the Panthalassan area and it provides important data for the study of crinoid recovery during the Early Triassic.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: Both authors acknowledge the kind support, encouragement and patience of Ruby Jenks (West Jordan, Utah) during this investigation. We thank Kevin G. Bylund (Spanish Fork, Utah), Daniel A. Stephen (Utah Valley University, Orem, Utah) and Noreen Kittrick (Salt Lake City, Utah) for their support on field trips. We are also grateful to Tatsuo Oji (Nagoya City Science Museum) and Frank Stiller (Nanjing Institute of Geology and Palaeontology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Nanjing, China) and Atsushi Yabe (Editor-in-Chief of Paleontological Research) for their advanced comments on the draft. This research was financially supported by the 2015 annual research grant of the Tokyo Geographical Society, the 2019 annual research grant of the Fukada Geological Institute (Fukada Grant-in-Aid), the 2020 Nakatsuji Foresight Foundation Research Grant, and Grant-in-Aids for Young Research (KAKENHI) from the Japan Society for the promotion of Science (21K14036) to T. Maekawa. Fossil localities pertinent to this study at the classic Crittenden Springs site lie on US public land (Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management). This study was conducted under the auspices of BLM Paleontological Resources Use Permit N-97816. We thank the BLM for allowing access to the fossil sites.
This article is licensed under a Creative Commons [Attribution 4.0 International] license.

sec.title: Author contributions
sec.p: T. M. and J. F. J. investigated outcrops of the Thaynes Formation at the classic Crittenden Springs site in Long Canyon and wrote this manuscript. T. M. collected conodont and crinoid samples. Both authors contributed to the writing of the paper.
